title: Stopping or delaying a US Government Wage Garnishment Order (SF-329B)
question: A family member went out of business and stopped paying back a Small Business Administration (SBA) loan. The SBA loan had a balance of $9000. After going out of business, the family member found a wage paying job.
answers:
Maybe. SBA debt may/not be dischargeable in BK.
Maybe. Actually filing BK results in Automatic Stay which stops debt collection activity. Thinking about filing BK does not always prompt creditor from proceeding with collection efforts.
No. Debt collection temporarily stopped when BK filed, not at later discharge date. Permanently stopped when discharge order entered.
Yes. If debt discharged, debt collection attempts forever barred.
Probably not. Granishment likely will not be waived or temporarily delayed due to financial hardship.
Time of essence. Consult BK counsel immediately to deal with wage garnishment order.

The family member receives no legal protection based on her intent to file bankruptcy. The strong protection of an automatic stay arises immediately upon filing one's bankruptcy case. The automatic stay will stop all collection activities by any creditor, including the family member's wage garnishment order based on SBA loans default. In many instances, an SBA loan is eligible for discharge assuming no fraud or other grounds for creditor's objection to discharge (or removing this particular debt from discharge...) is found and set forth by a creditor.

However, when considering filing for bankruptcy protection and relief it is nearly always essential to analyze a full range of factors that may give reason for caution related to any particular person (e.g., asset transfer, non-exempt assets, overly high income, etc., etc.).

BOTTOM LINE: before relying on bankruptcy as a solution, it is often wisest to consult with an experienced bankruptcy lawyer for a thorough analysis and to identify any possible problems.

The SBA loan might not be dischargeable in a BK. Your relative should consult with an experienced BK Attorney to find out.

A creditor is under no obligation to discontinue a wage garnishment until the debtor actually files BK. Notification of an intent to file has no effect. This is basic debt collection law but, because of the potential BK, your relative should consult with a BK Attorney.

It is only the actual filing of a bankruptcy that stops a wage garnishment. creditors are never impressed by statements of "gonna file tomorrow, or next week, or next month." It is either filed, and the garnishment stops, or it isn't filed, and the garnishment continues. The minute a bankruptcy is filed, the power of the bankruptcy court steps in to stop the garnishment.

Garnishment is a process controlled under state laws called exemptions, and these laws strictly define what can be taken and what defenses might be claimed. A link to general information about these laws is below.

The problem with most SBA loans is not discharging them in bankruptcy, but the fact that these loans are often highly secured by assets such as the family car, the retirement accounts, the furniture, the business inventory, etc. Clearly you are not aware of the whole story because I can assure you your family member has likely had many chances to work this out and ignored these opportunities. Hope this perspective helps!
